Limitations of variational quantum algorithms: a quantum optimal transport approach

Apr 17, 2023

Definitions

Definition 1. The Lipschitz constant for H a self-adjoint operator is defined by: ‚à•H‚à•L‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ2maxv‚ÄÑ‚àà‚ÄÑVminH\v‚à•H‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖH\v‚ÄÖ‚äó‚ÄÖùïÄv‚à•‚àû

Definition 2. The sandwiched Renyi divergence of order Œ±‚ÄÑ‚àà‚ÄÑ(1,+‚àû) is defined for two quantum states œÅ,‚ÄÜœÉ with supp‚ÄÜœÅ‚ÄÑ‚äÇ‚ÄÑsupp‚ÄÜœÉ as $$D_{\alpha} (\rho \| \sigma) = \frac{1}{\alpha-1} \log \mathrm{tr} \left[\left(\sigma^{\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} \rho \sigma^{\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}}\right )^\alpha\right]$$

Definition 3. A state œÉ on V qudits satisfies a Gaussian concentration inequality of parameter c if there is a constant K such that for any a and any observable O: $$\Pr_{\sigma} (|O - \langle O\rangle_\sigma \mathbb{I}| > a |V|) \leq K \exp \left( - \frac{c a^2 |V|}{\| \sigma^{-1/2} O \sigma^{1/2}\|_L^2}\right)$$

Above $|A| = \sqrt {A^\dagger A}$, and PrœÉ(|O‚àí‚ü®O‚ü©œÉùïÄ>a|V|) means that for E the positive part of |O‚àí‚ü®O‚ü©œÉùïÄ|‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖa|V|ùïÄ, we have $\mathrm{tr}(E\sigma)$ bounded by the right hand side of the equation. Note that in the cases where œÉ and O commute ‚à•œÉ‚àí1/2OœÉ1/2‚à•L2 reduces to ‚à•O‚à•L2.

Transferring inequalities

Theorem 1. Let œÅ,‚ÄÜœÉ be two quantum states on ‚ÑãV. Then for any POVM element 0‚ÄÑ‚â§‚ÄÑE‚ÄÑ‚â§‚ÄÑùïÄ and Œ±‚ÄÑ>‚ÄÑ1, $$\mathrm{tr}[E\rho] \leq \exp\left( \frac{\alpha -1}{\alpha} (D_\alpha(\rho\|\sigma) + \log(\mathrm{tr}[E\sigma]))\right)$$

Proof. Using the circularity of the trace we have: $$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{tr}[E\rho] & = \mathrm{tr}[\sigma^{-\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} E \sigma^{-\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} \times \sigma^{\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} \rho \sigma^{\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}}] \\ & \leq \left\{\mathrm{tr} \left[ \left( \sigma^{-\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} E \sigma^{-\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}}\right)^\beta \right ]\right\}^{\frac{1}{\beta}} \times \left\{\mathrm{tr} \left[ \left( \sigma^{\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} \rho \sigma^{\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} \right)^\alpha \right ]\right\}^{\frac{1}{\alpha}}\end{aligned}$$ where the last line is obtained by applying H√∂lder inequality, which holds for $\frac{1}{\alpha} + \frac{1}{\beta} = 1$.

Using the Araki-Lieb-Thirring inequality followed by E‚ÄÑ‚â§‚ÄÑùïÄ we obtain: $$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{tr} \left( \sigma^{-\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} E \sigma^{-\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}}\right)^\beta & \leq \mathrm{tr} \left( \sigma^{-\frac{(1-\alpha)\beta}{2\alpha}} E^\beta \sigma^{-\frac{(1-\alpha)\beta}{2\alpha}}\right) \\ & \leq \mathrm{tr} \left( \sigma^{-\frac{(1-\alpha)\beta}{2\alpha}} E \sigma^{-\frac{(1-\alpha)\beta}{2\alpha}}\right).\end{aligned}$$ As $\beta = \frac{\alpha}{\alpha -1}$ we have $$\mathrm{tr} \left( \sigma^{-\frac{(1-\alpha)\beta}{2\alpha}} E \sigma^{-\frac{(1-\alpha)\beta}{2\alpha}}\right)=\mathrm{tr}(E\sigma).$$

Additionally, note that $$\left \{ \mathrm{tr} \left[ \left( \sigma^{\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} \rho \sigma^{\frac{1-\alpha}{2\alpha}} \right)^\alpha \right ]\right\}^{\frac{1}{\alpha}} = \exp (\frac{\alpha -1}{\alpha} D_\alpha(\rho\|\sigma)).$$

Combining the two gives: $$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{tr}[E\rho] & \leq (tr[E\sigma]) \times \exp\left( \frac{\alpha -1}{\alpha} (D_\alpha(\rho\|\sigma))\right) \\ & \leq \exp\left( \frac{\alpha -1}{\alpha} (D_\alpha(\rho\|\sigma)) \log (\mathrm{tr}[E\sigma])\right).\end{aligned}$$¬†‚óª

Remark that the theorem bounds the probability of observing E on œÅ based on the product of the probability of observing E on œÉ times a quantity that depends on DŒ±(œÅ‚à•œÉ), which can be seen as a measure of the distance between the two states œÅ and œÉ. This will become interesting whenever DŒ±(œÅ‚à•œÉ) becomes small.

Corollary 1. If œÉ satisfies a Gaussian concentration inequality $$\Pr_{\sigma} (|O - \langle O\rangle_\sigma \mathbb{I}| > a |V|) \leq K \exp \left( - \frac{c a^2 |V|}{\| \sigma^{-1/2} O \sigma^{1/2}\|_L^2}\right)$$ for some constant c,‚ÄÜK‚ÄÑ>‚ÄÑ0, then for any Œ±‚ÄÑ>‚ÄÑ1: $$\Pr_{\rho} (|O - \langle O\rangle_\sigma \mathbb{I}| > a |V|) \leq \exp \left(\frac{\alpha -1}{\alpha}\left(D_\alpha(\rho\|\sigma) - \frac{c a^2 |V|}{\| \sigma^{-1/2} O \sigma^{1/2}\|_L^2} + \log(K)\right)\right)$$

Corollary 2. For an input state œÅ, a noisy circuit evolution ùí©(œÅ) and a state œÉ satisfying a Gaussian concentration inequality, whenever there is a value of Œ± and a such that $$\frac{D_{\alpha}(\mathcal N(\rho) \| \sigma)}{|V|} < \frac{c a^2}{\| \sigma^{-1/2} O \sigma^{1/2}\|_L^2} - \frac{\log(K)}{|V|},$$ then the probability of observing an outcome of O outside the interval ‚ü®O‚ü©œÉ‚ÄÖ¬±‚ÄÖa|V| decreases exponentially with |V|.

Bounding DŒ±(ùí©(œÅ)‚à•œÉ)

Such bounds can be obtained for noisy circuits where each layer i is followed by a noisy channel ùí© with a fixed point œÉ satisfying a strong data processing inequality: DŒ±(ùí©(œÅ)‚à•œÉ)‚ÄÑ‚â§‚ÄÑ(1‚àíq)DŒ±(œÅ‚à•œÉ),¬†‚àÄœÅ.

In such cases we obtain

Lemma 1. Let ùí© be a quantum channel with a unique fixed point œÉ and satisfying a strong data processing inequality for some Œ±‚ÄÑ>‚ÄÑ1, then for any other channels {Œ¶i}i‚ÄÑ‚â§‚ÄÑl we have: DŒ±(ùí´(œÅ)‚à•œÉ)‚ÄÑ‚â§‚ÄÑ(1‚àíq)lDŒ±(œÅ‚à•œÉ)‚ÄÖ+‚ÄÖ‚àëi‚ÄÑ‚â§‚ÄÑl(1‚àíq)l‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖiD‚àû(Œ¶i(œÉ)‚à•œÉ) where $D_\infty(\rho \| \sigma) = \log \| \sigma^{-\frac{1}{2}} \rho \sigma^{-\frac{1}{2}}\|_\infty$, and ùí´‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ‚àèi‚ÄÑ‚â§‚ÄÑlŒ¶i‚ÄÖ‚àò‚ÄÖùí©.

Proof. We proceed by induction on l. For l‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ1, we use the data processed triangle inequality: DŒ±(Œ¶1‚àòùí©(œÅ)‚à•œÉ)‚ÄÑ‚â§‚ÄÑDŒ±(ùí©(œÅ)‚à•œÉ)‚ÄÖ+‚ÄÖD‚àû(Œ¶1(œÉ)‚à•œÉ)‚ÄÑ‚â§‚ÄÑ(1‚àíq)DŒ±(œÅ‚à•œÉ)‚ÄÖ+‚ÄÖD‚àû(Œ¶1(œÉ)‚à•œÉ). The induction is performed in the same way, assuming the property holds for some l and then applying the data processed triangle inequality.¬†‚óª

Note that for unital channels ùí©(œÉ)‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑœÉ as the fixed point of the channel is ùïÄ. This implies that DŒ±(ùí´(œÅ)‚à•œÉ) will always converge to 0.

Additional notes

Renyi entropies

In the above definition of Renyi divergence, note that when Œ±‚ÄÑ‚Üí‚ÄÑ1 we recover the usual relative entropy: $$D_1 (\rho \| \sigma) = \mathrm{tr}(\rho (\log \rho - \log \sigma))$$

This is not a surprise as these sandwiched Renyi divergences have been introduced as a generalization of the usual relative entropy. Renyi entropies $\frac{1}{1-\alpha} \log \frac{\mathrm{tr} \rho^\alpha}{\mathrm{tr} \rho}$ are also generalizations of von Neumann entropy in that they preserve important properties:

  • Continuity

  • Unitary invariance

  • Normalization

  • Additivity.

Relative entropy and Pinsker inequality

The Pinsker inequality relates the relative entropy to the trace distance. As such it allows to bound the trace distance using information theoretic arguments: $$D_1(\rho\|\sigma) \geq \frac{1}{2\log 2} \| \rho -\sigma \|_{\mathrm{tr}}^2$$

H√∂lder inequality

For A, B operators on ‚Ñã $$\|AB\|_1 \leq \|A\|_p \|B\|_q, \quad \frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} = 1$$ which translates for matrices into $$\mathrm{tr}(|AB|) \leq [\mathrm{tr}(|A|^{p})]^{1/p} \times [\mathrm{tr}(|B|^{q})]^{1/q}, \quad \frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} = 1.$$

Araki-Lieb-Thirring inequality

For A,‚ÄÜB‚ÄÑ‚â•‚ÄÑ0, q‚ÄÑ‚â•‚ÄÑ0 and 0‚ÄÑ‚â§‚ÄÑr‚ÄÑ‚â§‚ÄÑ1 then $$\mathrm{tr}[(A^rB^rA^r)^q] \leq\mathrm{tr}[(ABA)^{rq}].$$ When r‚ÄÑ‚â•‚ÄÑ1 the inequality is reversed.
